reviewText:
The good:
- innovative and almost unique game play with RTS-commander, lots of weapons, abilities and possible strategies
- two totally different yet balanced teams
- the developer Unknown Worlds Entertainment is very committed to the game and has published several free content upgrades since launch
- shiny and polished graphics
- small but stable and very committed community

The bad:
- some players report performance issues
- the game stands and falls with its players/potentially frustrating

Counterstrike meets Starcraft:

Some people describe this game as a shooter with a supporting commander for each team. It is not! It is a fully grown RTS with real players as units. This is important to understand if you want to have fun with it.

I've seen my share of marketing claims asserting game X would really endorse team play. They all lied. Not so with Natural Selection 2. It doesn't endorse" team play
date: it simply makes it a requirement for victory. You need your team
recommended: your team needs its commander and the commander needs the team to follow his orders. It's a symbiosis.\n\nThis is the strongest part of Natural Selection 2 and it's the feature that sets it apart from other games. In a way it could be seen as a game about leadership
hoursPlayed: and at the end of the day
voteText: when everybody knows the tech-tree and how to deal with opponents and the commander has learned the "best build order" and the countless possible strategies there is still work to do. Sometimes the biggest challenge seems to be to keep the team's morale up. This is where communication comes into play
helpfulPercent: an important part of the game. It is incredibly rewarding to overcome a worthy opponent and there are no achievements or unlockables in this game. Winning itself is the achievement.\n\nAnd if there's no teamwork? Well
votesHelpful: that's when Natural Selection 2 gets incredibly frustrating. Especially veterans can often tell how a game will end after 30 seconds. And it's always YOUR fault. See that NooB over there? YOU need to talk to him and make him follow you. It's impossible for the commander to take care of every single player.\n\nIf you just want to casually shoot some Aliens
votesTotal: this is probably not your game
votesFunny: but if you want to enjoy team play and are willing to commit to a degree: don't wait any longer.\n\nIt's regularly on sale for €2
commentsCount: 49. There is hardly any reason to not at least give it a try!"

reviewText: Everything runs great on GNU/Linux. The graphics are awesome and the gameplay is just amazing! This game has the most emergent teamplay I've ever seen, even better than in TF2! Also, it has no hat-cancer (just donors badges and minor skins which are purely cosmetc) and no ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥s of guns focusing on balancing two completely different factions instead. You play RTS as a commander directing your brave troops or as a mighty alien/marine fighting your way to the enemy's base and helping your commander to build and defend structures.\n\nYou always have to cooperate with your teammates, playing solo leads to dying all the time even if you buy a heavy unit like EXO or Onos. You can be strong but not almighty if you don't have your back covered. The game also requires listening to the environment so don't play with any music turned on (except the in-game one). Hearing enemy movement can save lots of your buildings and comrades.

reviewText:
One of the best indie multiplayers games i have ever played.

To describe it first i would say it's a mix of Counterstrike meets Starcraft.

You play either a soldier/alien (FPS) or the commander commanding your teammates, upgrading weapons, abilities and building new bases etc. (RTS).

Basically the game is a fight between aliens and marines about ressouces nodes all over the map, to buy better stuff or evolve into better classes by the gained ressources.

A pretty interessting point in this game is also that you loose all your bought stuff as soldier once you die, so you just don't want to die and therefor most ppl play alot more tactical than they would in any other games.

Only things you should be aware before buying this game is that it needs pretty high specs to run smooth, that it requires alot time to learn and master all things, that it's hard to get into at first.

If you are aware of those things i guarantee you alot of fun with this game ;)

TL;DR:

Pros:
- Interessting Mix of RTS and FPS
- Asynchron Teams (Aliens and Marines)
- Alot Tactical Teamplay
- Fast-Paced Action Combat
- Devs are supporting game still after 1 year after release

Cons:
- Steep Learning Curve (about 100-500 h)
- Needs high specs to run smooth
- Server Browser is missing some features
- No real matchmaking (yet)

reviewText:
I recommend against the purchase of this game.
I admit, I haven't given this game too much of my time.  And yet, I don't feel as though I am being unjust.

<Quick Overview>
pros:
fun
fast paced
team work based

cons:
Game is possibly abandoned (no regular updates)
extremely long load times
servers are empty (hardly anyone plays this game anymore)
non stop yelling
not beginner friendly
poor balancing (aliens are superior)

<Indepth Review>

In Natural Selection 2, you play on the side of the Marines or the aliens.
The two sides use a combination of RTs style structure building (the commander) and first person shooting (everyone else). The two sides have upgrades, structures, team work, and their brains to best the other side.

This game is fun, It'll kill sometime if you're bored. However, it gets old very fast for a large number of reason.
1) You can tell from the Christmas splashpage" on the title screen
date: that this game does not recieve many updates. It is nearly February and we are still being shown Christmas images.\n\n2) The game's connection and loading speeds are awful. In order to connect to the "tutorial"
recommended: I was subject to an unbelievably long time period. I was able to boil some pasta and prepare myself a nice carbonara before it was done loading.\n\n3) When connecting to the server list
hoursPlayed: one can see many servers. Unfortunately
voteText: there are only 10 or less servers that are actually being used. On average
helpfulPercent: the servers hold 10 people. This is a good indication that this game is dead and plaers have abandoned it for its many flaws.\n\n4)Advanced players of this game have no room for beginners. They will scream and belittle anyone who doesn't understand the game mechanics immediately. The only reason they won't kick you
votesHelpful: is because there is strength in numbers.\n\nIf you'd like a "get yelled at" simulation
votesTotal: then this game may be for you.\n\n5) Aliens have an advantage in this game. The aliens are capable of very quick movements. WIth how shooting is implemented in this game
votesFunny: it is disasterous for the marines. Therefore
commentsCount:
everoyne wants to play on the alien side and you are left with an unbalanced team.

<Conclusion>
It's a fun game
column16: but save your money. The many flaws of this game has led it to lose its player base.\nI'd consider it if it was on a great sale (75% off and up) and if I had many friends that were interested in playing."

reviewText: Great on paper but a buggy, glitchy, obtuse and convoluted game overall. What's the point of a shooter if the shooting ain't fun and exciting to begin with? There's barely any satisfactory gun feedback. The enemy animations are risible and the way they attack/charge at you from like 5 meters away it's just silly. NS2 features one of the most unnecessarily intricate level designs I've seen in my entire gaming life for these type of shooters, there's no flow to them, it's a chore to travel back and forth between rooms, it's a labyrinthic mess. The engine, as far as I know, it's not based on UE3 so 'featuring' texture pop-in -that takes even minutes to load- it's even more bizarre. The performance is terrible overall, very unoptimized and it doesn't look that hot to begin with, the pictures are really misleading. Add to that the extremely long, annoying load times -even for a training match with bots-.\n\nA shame really, it looked like it could have improved on Aliens vs Predator and delivered what Colonial Marines didn't on the MP aspect. Good thing I got it on a Humble Bundle for cheap. But don't listen to Bixby Snyder, don't buy this even for a dollar!

reviewText: Having played this game for so long and giving it another try, I remember well I stopped playing in the first place.  The two teams are not just asymmetrical, they are outright unbalanced.  So much so that a single, high tier player is all it takes to decide the game.  There is just no way to deal with how crazy some of their aiming capabilities are or ability to dodge as aliens.  This fact along makes the game a chore to play, add in the learning curve and the fact that UWE has never been good at balancing the gameplay.  The original NS had significant imbalance issues that took practically the entire development of that mod to finally iron out, by then it was desolate of an active, teeming player base.\n\nNatural Selection 2 is a game with great setting, art style, and technical chops.  It is a shame the core gameplay can be so lopsided and difficult to work through.  Add in that the developers have for all intents and purposes abandoned the game to the community.  That is the death knell of a game, from here on out it is just running on the original steam from its release.

reviewText:
My beef with this game is that it rewards only those who understand the glitches and overpowered techniques in this game. For example. Using a skork unit and trying to ambush a skilled marine will result in the marine hopping out of sight and into the air while doing a 360 turn midair, while reloading, then shooting you once with the shotgun and you are dead.

Forget about the 10 minutes it took you to sneak up to this player. Attacking someone in the back will result in the human jumping in to the air and dodging all future melee attacks. It takes up to 4 melee attacks to kill a marine. this makes it so that you cannot sneak attack players and be rewarded for your stealth. The only time sneak attacks will work are when you attack a noob marine.

This is why I quit the game because stealth is not rewarded and only those players who have been playing this for ages will win the fights because they know all the ridiculous glitches to come on top of a fight no matter what you do.

I also think that late game, these massive units appear in the game where players control a mech or a giant dinosaur rhino, kind of ruin it completely. Things look really arcady and cheesy sometimes. Especially when all the marines hop around jumping higher in the air than the actual aliens.

I didnt want to play NS2. It didnt look appealing to me at all, but my friend forced me to play it. And I havent stopped since. Im not good at making friends and Im always scared of new places and new people. And messing up.

reviewText:
I have played many many hours with Natural Selection 2 and for the most part, I have greatly enjoyed my experience. My feelings about it are very complex, as it's a bold and innovative step in FPS multiplayer, has excellent developer support, and a pretty good community to boot. There are frequent updates and gameplay balances, and a new map is released roughly every six months or so. The two opposing factions are assymetrically balanced and gameplay is varied and interesting. So much so that you don't mind playing the same few maps over and over again countless times. In some respects, this game has pretty much everything going for it.

Sadly, I simply cannot recommend Natural Selection 2 for one very specific reason. The game's greatest strength is its ability to seamlessly blend the RTS experience with the FPS experience, and when you have a team that works well together, under a commander who knows the ropes, this game offers one of the most fun multiplayer experiences available.

It is this same strength which is also the game's greatest flaw. Very often - almost always - your experience is entirely dependant on the person in the command chair. To begin with, no one ever wants to be commander. You will sometimes spend as much as 10 minutes waiting for someone's patience to wear thin enough that they finally get into the command chair, at which point you are at their mercy. Sometimes you will even spend longer waiting for the commander than the actual game lasts.

If this person happens to be you, your command experience will go one of three ways: 1) You will do an excellent job and everyone will love you for it, in which case your game will likely be over very quickly. 2) You will do an excellent job and everyone will hate you for it anyway, because you didn't build X thing at Y time. They will complain at you for arbitrary reasons, even though you are winning the game. 3)You will do a bad job and everyone will hate you for it, likely resulting in you being kicked from the command position, ostricized, and ruining everyone's fun.

Additionally, while the game is quite expertly balanced, it takes very little to upset that balance. A bad or good commander can mean everything in a game, and very often the fun and enjoyment of as many as 24 people hinges on that commander's ability to play the game. It's not uncommon to spend hours going from stacked game to stacked game because teams just can't seem to turn out right. And then, when that magical golden ratio finally occurs, and the game looks like it's going to be a long, bloody, brutal fight to the death, someone rushes your base and the game is over before you have time to check the map.

So, while I have had some real fun with Natural Selection 2, at the end of the day I just can't recommend a game with such a massive, fundamental, and irreversible flaw. The average player just has to put in way too much effort and patience to squeeze the fun out of this game. But I do admit that if you manage to do so, you will be in for quite a treat.

reviewText: Being dishearted about the total failure of Gearbox to give us good humans vs aliens fps, I bought this game having heard that it was similar but better. I had aton of spare xmas cash left over and I figured, sure, why not try Natural Selection out? This game is, to put it mildly, THE best indie game and one of the greatest shooter games out there. I love this game primarily, however, for two things. One is that this games isn't afraid to accept thje fact that in an actual battle there are actually commanders and ammo supplies to work with, and though some players used to the make-it-up-as-you-go-along format that most multiplayer shooters seem to follow might resent having another plaayer over them acting as boss, but the game does great job at creating a symbiotic relationship between commander and soldiers. Second, this game does something really well that Colonial Marines direly lacked. The akiens are increbily fun to play. There are few more entertaining moments in multiplayer games in my opinion than stalking a squad of hapless players on the human team as an invisible fade and killing them off one by one. An all-around great game.

reviewText:
Natural Selection 2 (NS2) Is a First person shooter real time strategy  (FPSRTS) game (multiplayer only)

It is a game designed for the more hardcore gamers and the learning curve of this game is steep,  however, once you get to know the game and how the mechanics work it is one of the most addictive games around. It is updated reguarly

There are tutorials in this game that will give you some of the basics but it is a lot to take in and it will take about 20-30 hours of playtime to get the basics in. Not to worry though, there are plenty of rookie's like yourself out there and there are server designed to help out new players.


The game requires an up to date computer with a high-end graphics card to play the game in all it's detail, but even with my GTX660 while playable in the highest settings I prefer to set it on low to gain this extra FPS for aiming.

If you're a bit of a hardcore gamer this game can be your next addictive game for a long time, but if you're a casual players and don't have much time to invest, this won't be the game for you.

Pro's

- Great gameplay combo
- Good Graphics
- Great community
- Price, 2,29 when 90% off

Cons

- Steep learning curve
- Requires a fast PC with high end Graphics card

reviewText:
- 9 / 10 -

NS2 is a fast-paced action FPS, heavily reliant on team-work, strategy & twitch reactions. It's a unique blend of FPS with real-time strategy elements. It pits two teams (Aliens VS Marines) against each-other in online matches. Graphics are very nice, performance is ok - the custom made engine (Spark) does seem to be quite CPU demanding, yet a comprehensive options menu allow for various tweaking. Gameplay is awesome, sound assets are okay.

It's good fun, competitive, but also newbie friendly. Has a great community that are steadily active (so you'll always be able to find a game). It's essentially a game about map / resource control, upgrading / evolution tech research & using various weapons / skills & abilities - it's pretty sweet.

As a huge fan of both the original HL1 mod & the indie dev team, I must admit I wasn't too impressed with the initial release due to bugs, performance issues, lack of content & balancing issues - yet true to their word UWE rolled out (& continue to do so) patches / updates & free content, fully addressing my intial concerns. I fully respect UWE approch to the development process where they where open to community suggestions & really made an effort to involve players with the process even from pre-order. If not even pioneering the technique of early-access / beta release with ongoing development.

This is a must play for any action FPS fan!

reviewText:
Natural Selection 2 is a amazing concept and makes for amazing game play especially if you have friends. A lot of people complain about the community being “Too Veteran” or “God-Like” and that makes it hard for new players. I say that this is true, but they can't help it if they have played the game for so long. If you are completely new, I recommend Bot matches against the computer even if others don't recommend it

Bot matches are not designed to be challenging for veterans, but if you are new they are very helpful. They allow you to explore the games systems and try-out everything. Things that may be too expensive for you to risk buying in a real match in fear of screwing up. The hardest difficulty Bot matches actually are challenging for new players so don't listen to people who say “Playing Bot matches will ruin your skills forever” or stupid comments like that because they are not true.

Once you are ready (which can take a load of bot matches to reach), try a easy multilayer match and see how you go. Even if you lose you can learn from the experience.

Don't fall into the trap of buying the game, getting really exited, immediately joining a multiplayer match, get totally destroyed by other players and then stop playing the game because its “too hard”.

If you are desperate for some multilayer action you can try to create a server (if you know how ;_;) or join a empty server and invite your friends. Really great game! Just don't be surprised about the difficulty level. It is a hard game!

reviewText: Damn solid  multiplayer game. Although the learning curve is pretty tremendous  for what seems to be a simple AVP concept, the reality is that Natural Selection 2 involves requiring strategy that most games do not. Each of the two teams of Aliens and Marines have one commander, a person who assumes a top view of the map and can order his soldiers to go to a certian location, complete an objective, upgrade their armor and weaponry, and build structures to fortify the main base and make their team more powerful. I have found that the community for NS2 is generally helpful to rookies, and most (not all) will give tips and advise to new players struggling with the heavy expectations for a team in the matches that can last upwards of half an hour. Occasionally you witness the gruff veteran who lacks patience for the new recruits, but you can pick up on the game mechanics fairly quickly before they nag at you consistently. The gameplay is solid and balanced, playing as either team is fun and enjoyable. Playing as the vulnerable aliens as you stalk your prey can be exhilierating, but hunting the agile opponets with a pulse rifle can be equally enjoyable. The best game involves high levels of cooperation for all, but when you win, it feels great to have contributed to a team and I think I can say the level of comradery felt between two people is greatest when you squinting in the dimly light power room trying to reconstruct power to get the lights on as knee-high aliens shoot acidic goo at your feet. Fantastic game at any price, and it is gaurenteed to last you quite a while.

reviewText:
Never played the original NS1, but one day, i've decided to just buy NS2. Don't know what made me buy it, i just sort of felt the need to do it. And man i'm glad i did it. There is so much stuff going on in this game it's just not possible to write it down in a reasonably short review.

It's a blend of FPS and strategy game with great emphasis on team work. Because on your own, you're are a dead man/dead alien. Granted, hours and hours of training will give you a huge edge over new players, but doing it as a team helps even more.
There are so many upgrades, different weapons, vehicles, tactics, methods of attacking, methods of coordinating attacks, exploiting environment and different paths, abilities. It's just insane and awesome!

One thing that i recommend is that you get yourself a decent headphones with mic. Because the only way to play this game is to hear the team and communicate in real-time. Typing stuff is just too time consuming and clumsy. Keeping team up to date with combat status can often be a matter of win or lose. And don't even think of commanding without a headset. You just need it to do the job right.

There is one special thing about this game, while it was made by indie developer, the game apart from occasional balance issues feels like a proper high profile AAA multiplayer game. It just all feels really professional, well executed and polished.

Did i mention the graphics look absolutely amazing? It's incredible what kind of graphics engine they developed themselves for this game. I wish they'd sell it to other developers, because the worlds, models, effects and the lighting and shading itself is sometimes so realistic you could almost mistaken it for a photo. I'm not kidding!

Natural Selection 2 is a multiplayer based game where 2 teams (Aliens and Marines) must battle it out to best your opponent by evolving the way you play, literally evolving... that’s an actual mechanic... but not like the, it takes millions of years to grow feet because, well you already have them.

How does the multiplayer, well, play?
It is actually quite a nice blend of strategy and first person carnage, each team has a commander, it’s up to the commander to distribute orders for both buildings and troops and also upgrade their soldiers to be the best they can be in a battle. Now this does take a bit of skill, a dash of map knowledge and a whole heaping of luck, to get a good team of experienced players that is. Sounds a bit intimidating doesn't it, stop being such a baby, there’s a very instructive tutorial you can play through before you jump into the action for both Alien and Marine commanders and also their infantry counterparts.

Speaking of the infantry, they're pretty fun to play as also, at first the gameplay will feel a bit hectic, the map is bigger than your usual CoD map and there are a lot of different angles and vents the Alien horde can come at you from but once you gain a bit of map knowledge and you learn the ropes a little you'll be murdering hundreds and hundreds of Aliens that for all we know might just be expressing their need for a cuddle or a wingman to go to the club with... I dunno.

The alien infantry isn't that bad either, with a wide variety of Aliens to choose from you'll be spoiled for choice when it comes to evolving you little alien demon. You can either stay as the stock Skulk, a vicious and acrobatic killer with a deadly bite attack and low damage ranged assault that can mark your enemies for your teammates. Or maybe the supportive Gorge who acts as the team medic and can also build great walls of erm... unknown body fluids to block pathways to objectives or to shoehorn your enemy into an ambush... Tactics!

Whatever you choose to play you can have a ruddy good time blasting holes in aliens using a variety of weapons and gadgets such as jetpacks and mech suits with big ol' guns on them or on the flips side you could turn into a flying alien or that invisible one or even better the massive rhino/triceratops that makes me cry on the inside.

To sum it up, Aliens, Space soldiers, Big guns, Big aliens, decent controls, great gameplay, small learning curve as long as you put the time in and most of all overall fun, fun, fun.

reviewText:
Realy fun game, once you get the hang of it.

A match can last from 2 minutes (poor balanced teams) to ~45 minutes (good balanced teams), but stands on an avarage of ~30 minutes per match.

Before joining a NS2 match everyone should know that this is no deathmatch or tdm. This game mode is a combination of tactical and strategical gameplay.

The key for victory in this game is communication between the team, even if you are a bad shoot.
Beeing aware and knowing were and when to go can make the difference between win/loss and kill/death ratio.

For my part I enjoy the alien lifeforms most, which rather rely on speed, stealth and clever gameplay with different playstyle.
But the Marines do not stand behind with nice gadgets, like jetpacks, flamethrowers or exosuits with miniguns or railguns.

But there are some things to learn before anyone can think of having a nice K/D ratio, so I recommend watching some basic tutorials.
Even more I recommend using the ingame voice chat to ask questions if you are having difficulty in understandig the game or don't know what to do.
The differention of rookie servers(marked green) and experienced servers(marked white) is a nice feature, and asking for help understanding the game is never wrong.

reviewText:
This game is a true competitive FPS. Natural Selection 2 is an extremely underated game. It combines FPS action with RTS elements to make one of the most unique games you'll ever play.

I've sunk in nearly 800 hours so far and I can honestly say every round I have played has been different. Rookies tend to get discouraged at first because of the steep learning curve, but stick with it for a couple of hours and you will NEVER want to play anything remotely similiar to CoD or BF.

I could sit here and go on and on about how great this game is and how it deserves much more attention. Instead I will throw a couple of negative things out there to be fair.

The optimization is pretty bad. You don't need a super computer to run it or anything. Personally, I play on a three year old laptop.

i7 2.3 Ghz
8 Gb Ram
660M GTX

I can still normally run games on at least medium settings, but not Natural Selection 2. Even on mostly low settings, I only average 35 FPS. Another problem seems to be hit registration. There have been many times where I've shot lifeforms point blank (and see alien blood) yet I ended up doing zero damage. Other times, I'm an alien WELL around a corner and I'm still taking bullet damage.

Those are my only two complaints. Do they keep me from playing? Obviously not. Is it gamebreaking? No. Should you get this game? No question.

reviewText:
Natural Selection 2 is a great game, it can be hard to learn, hard to play at times, but once you get through that barrier then you will see how much of a great game this is,

All the Negative reviews lately comes down to some users not liking some changes being made by the Dev's -

They now support Large player count servers 42 players etc. as a game mod called NS2 LARGE,
Before UWE did not support them, with these users they Threatened to give only Negative reviews of this game until that change is reverted, as they feel this killed their server. Just one server. That was only moved to another server mode filter.

This is a great game, and these recent reviews are damaging enough for any new players looking at them, IF you are looking for a new game, something challenging then this is for you, you won’t notice any of these recent changes as they will all be still new to you, give this game a go, you won’t regret it.

reviewText:
I believe Natural Selection 2 is a masterpiece of a game, that represents the perfect blend of FPS and RTS game play. It is one of the few games where teamwork and individual skill are highly rewarded. On top of that, the community is accepting of new players and offers a friendly hand to educate those who are new.

Due to the fact that Natural Selection 2 is a hybrid of FPS and RTS game play, it allows for very competitive play in that the deciding factor of victory and defeat involves the long term decisions of a commander and/or the quick reactions and overall skill of the individual combatants (whether shooting aliens, or stalking marines). Due to this style of game play, games can very well last over an hour and yet feel very tight" throughout the entire match.

reviewText:
This is an excellent team based shooter, with marines vs. aliens, trying to kill each other's base. Add to that, each team has a commander that sees the map from overhead and uses team resources to build structures to aid this team, while directing his team to work together to grab objectives.

The interaction between the commander and his team works very well and the majority of the community are actually nice, helpful people. There are a lot of variation in marine weapons and equipment and alien creatures but for new players this also means a bit steeper learning curve than usual for a shooter. Luckily, there's a tutorial, ingame hints and a single player sandbox mode with or without bots to help getting started. Also there are rookie servers for new players so you won't get completely stomped by veterans.

If you like the idea of having to defend a dark, creepy corridor with your fellow marines against vicious aliens charging with more teeth than you can count, assaulting a nasty alien hive with grenade launchers, mechsuits and jet packs, sneak around the ceiling only to jump down and bite the head off an unsuspecting marine or charging a group of panicking marines with a massive dinosaur sized alien, this game won't let you down.

Go get it. Now. The hive mind commands it.

reviewText: This game is a fantastic blend of RTS and FPS with the players choice dictating how they play. The Alien and Marine teams aren't exactly equal as the Marines have more ranged weapons and the Aliens have melee and close ranged attacks along with two or three ranged attacks and also have a greater utilization of the map as they can climb walls and enter vents. The commander plays it like an RTS yet each unit is an actual player. It's a fantastic game that requires some team play and lets you really get invested in each match. You will soon find the team and weapons that suit you and you'll fit comfortabley right into the game. If you ever played Tremulous or Gloom, which are amazing mods based off the same concept as they were the first to try this split team dynamic, then you will certainly enjoy this updated version of the classic style of FPS.

reviewText:
A very well put together RTS/FPS Hybrid in a sci-fi setting with 3D-printed people, railguns and one hell of a bacterial infection.

The game features asymmetrical combat between the more traditional marines who play as you would expect with typical shooter fare such as LMGs (the defauilt gun), shotguns and grenades. Reliant upon squad tactics and logistical support the marines may be more familiar, but require solid aim and awareness.

The alien infestation are worlds apart, with a mix of disposable skulks, dog like aliens very similar in play to runner aliens from the early AvP games; through to Fades and Onoses, much more specialised lifeforms that are important to keep alive. The aliens are build around hit an run tactics and guerilla warfare; breaking supply and picking off isolated pockets to keep the marines on the defensive.

The RTS aspect is really what makes the game special, there is macro and micro required. Commanders (limited to one lucky person per side) placing Resource Towers to allow marines to get new weapons and upgrades and aliens to evolve, and also being able to provide more direct help to his footsoldiers by dropping medpacks, ammo and scans.

The game is very slick without being dumbed down, and is based on team work and strong tactics without being clunky. The game looks beautiful, but that has not been at the expense of gameplay.

The one thing I cannot account for is the community, whilst I have had mostly positive experiences the game relies upon teamwork; thus, people not working as part of the team or following the commander's suggestions will be dead weight, something that will get on everybody's nerves. Rokkies are flagged up, and the developers have tried to encourage a forgiving environment, but trust me when I say there is one golden rule...

Do as you are asked: you will have a lot more fun that way.

reviewText:
One of the most fun and interesting multiplayer shooters. Oh, and its VERY arcade!

The game has two competing sides that play vastly differently, which is something rarely seen in multiplayer games, especially shooters. Playing as aliens is nothing like playing marines. Moreover, commanding makes the game actually a Real Time Strategy with other players as your units! However,  each side is limited to one commander, so if you enjoy NS2 as RTS, then you might have a hard time playing it this way when there are other players who want to be a commander too.

Nonetheless, there's a lot to enjoy in this game when played as FPP too. Not only because every unit (as aliens) and every different weapon (as humans) changes the style of the gameplay, but also because the game is quite intense and atmospheric (this is probably the best looking game I have ever seen too!). I highly recommend checking this game to everyone who like multiplayer action games, especially the arcade ones.

The only drawbacks I can think of are infuriating loading times. I have never seen a game that would load maps even one third of a time as a NS2 maps load. This is quite annoying.

reviewText: Natural Selection 2 offers a promising combination of strategy and first-person shooting, but disappointing execution holds it back. It is unquestionably a unique title, but its bar to entry is incredibly high for the average FPS player. For the hardcore strategist, it has its appeal, but its complexity severely limits the enjoyment in matches that aren’t significantly populated by experts at the game.Still, I am sure Natural Selection 2 will gather a group of devoted fans. After all it’s a surprisingly original game.

reviewText:
+ Complex Strategy
+ Marines and Aliens are well-balanced
+ Variety of weapons/lifeforms gives the game a lot of replay value
+ Commander Interface is easy to manouver; Alerts allow easy reactions to team requests
+ Well-made Futuristic visuals for marines and Organic visuals for Aliens
+ High-quality Audio
+ Smooth animations + Good netcode
+ Rookie-Friendly servers encourage a polite, respectable community

- Very Long loading time for maps without a high-tier PC w/ SSD
- Needs a more in-depth tutorial, especially for commander.
- A vote or timed command to randomise a commander would help with the problem of having to wait for a commander for 5-10 minutes before the game starts, every game
- Randomise Ready Room vote should allocate people evenly based on their skill levels, to help balance out teams
- Force Even Teams vote does not make the teams even consistently
- Glitch where dropping a medpack as commander will sometimes drop it on top of the map instead of in the room (I think this has been patched)

9/10.

reviewText: This game is really different, and really interesting. Take tactical teamplay games like CS. Take futuristic RTS like Starcraft. Take a bit of MOBA games (I know, that does not sound good, but bare with me), a bit of FPS games, a bit of tactical games like Rainbow 6, and put them all together and shake. Yes, there is ALL that. And the thing is, it is done with great honesty, authenticity and seriousness. Developers did it with their heart, you can see it. Now ALL I wish, was that I had free time like when I was younger, that I had all my friends around me in LAN like when WE were younger, and to play for hours on that game. Because then it would be awesome. Without it, meh, it is just ok. But because of that potential that lucky people can exploit if they have time and friends, well, then I DO recommend that game to you, lucky ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥s.

reviewText:
One word to describe NS2: unique. So what does it offer?

- hybrid FPS/RTS (the only other game I know about that does the same is Nuclear Dawn, but ND has been abandonned    by its devs and is pretty much dead)
- two completely different teams with different upgrades, tech trees, weapons, etc. encouraging different strategies
- a lot of room for in-depth teamwork
- each match is different, even on the same map = high replay value (btw maps are awesome)
- unlike most RTS, NS2 allows for surprising comebacks (too many careless mistakes by players with high value classes/equipment can cripple the winning team very hard)
- high skill ceiling (play with people of same skill or you'll be frustrated)
- constant updates

Many of the old negative reviews do not apply anymore, as the game now puts you against people of same skill. I got this game when it was on sale for 5€, but to be honest even 10€ is a joke. Steam is full of ♥♥♥♥ games which are more expensive and don't even get close to the amount of content and replay value that NS2 offers.
Don't get confused by the DLC, as I did. NS2 is not pay to win, everything is unlocked in the game. The DLCs are only skins, and most likely they will disappear soon anyways (one already did) due to the new NS2 item store. So expect more customization possibilites in the future.

If you think about buying this: do it. There simply is no other game like this.

reviewText:
I purchased this game back when the mega pack was on sale in November last year.
It looked very interesting to play with the fps/rts elements within it.
Back THEN I could log-in, load the server list up, pick just about any server I wanted, and then play. Siege was a lot of fun and kept me coming back for a couple of months. However I can't recommend this game I bought less than a year ago because: 1. Player population dropped significantly.
2. 80% of the games servers are completely empty.
3. Nearly every server nowadays is literally in the 200+Ping redzone.
4. They got rid of Siege gamemode and mostly favored making the game more difficult for an already tough game.

I enjoyed it greatly, the community at the time was fun to play with. People strategized and worked together at the time, but unfortunately those days are gone.
I do hope the server populations increase, the game gets better balanced, and siege comes back. But other than that this game is literally un-playable.

reviewText:
RTS meets FPS.

Fantastic blend of both and something I wish was blended together more with games.

Rather hard learning curve but once masted it, the game soon becomes rather enjoyable  and fun.

Trying to learn commander is hard to do tho, long time players tend to want to take the seat so that the team wins but the downside being new guys can never learn or put their RTS minds to the test.

I hope that CDT stay with us and keep this game alive because this game is a rare one to find with such an intresting idea.

For £6.99 you can't really complain....I got this at launch (forgot the price) But it has improved so much since then and for the asking price well....Amazing!

reviewText:
An excellent over-looked and under-appreciated team-based FPS that uniquely combines RTS elements in a way that just works.

Think Starship Troopers: The Game. and you're starting to get the idea.

Pretty decent mature age community when people are online, and the game has in-built voice chat which everyone tends to use which makes communicating with the team more pleasant than in most games. Usually, you would think joining a voice chat with a group of strangers would be a nightmare - but its actually okay in this game - why I'm not sure.

reviewText: Its the best multiplayer strategy fps hybrid game on the market. It is also the only fps game that can truly call itself a strategic mutliplayer FPS game, no other fps game comes even close. The game is all, and I mean 100% all, about skill, strategy, and on your feet tactical decision making. The game has a steep learning curve, but there are rookie only servers and tons of guides and tutorials so you will not be overwhelmed. In order to play, you have to have a microphone, it really is that strategic and cooperative focused. The game also does assymetrical warfare in a great way, and it stays feeling fresh and fun for hundreds of hours.\nIf you ever want strategy in your FPS or action in your RTS this is the only game for you.\n

reviewText:
Natural Selection 2 hit a draught in the gaming industry, the market was overflooded with yearly titles and streamlined content. Along came a stand alone sequel to one of the greatest mods to Half-Life 1.

It launched with an editor. This was a HUGE deal at the time. You didn't have the option of the free UE4 Engine,  and all of the major titles on the market were booming the DLC deal.

Player retention hasn't been good in Natural Selection 2, but the game deserve so much more play than it does. One of the reasons is that it's an old school titel, with roots in the mindset of the hl1 times. Getting good as either marine or alien takes time and practice, also a fair bit of knowledge, and on top of that you have the commander aspect which is basicly an RTS game with real players (some may act like AI's).

Not many players has the patience of old times, where people would defrag in a mod for Quake3, for weeks, only to outrick their opponents movement wise the in their matches.

TLDR:

- Getting gud is hard. (like in the old days)
- The game is awesome and have one of the best communities of all time, who are all happy to help / teach new players.
- Active forum / steam community.
- All it really needs is more players.

10/10

*Plushie Gorge's may cause cuteness overload*

reviewText:
If you start Rocket League, your goal is simple: Get the ball in the other team's goal by bumping it with your car! Everything else is a small accessory to that goal.

By comparison, just knowing the basics of Natural Selection 2 is a catacomb of logic. It makes you realize why games like TF2 and even Battlefield now focus on the idea of just having single-objective maps; diverting your focus between the five things going on at any time is often near-impossible. This is combined with very precise control requirements for each of the characters involved. For a marine, a skulk can jump across 30 degrees of your vision in less than half a second, and as any alien, having a constant arena awareness to make use of mobility is an immense challenge.

This does two things. The high skill floor causes a massive divide between skill levels. For instance, a bad skulk will get 1 kill in an entire game, and a good skulk will be undefeatable even to basic enemy marines. Second, it causes any team failure to become heavily compounded. If you've played a TF2 game with just one team member AFK, you tend to notice it. In NS2, just having someone not doing 20 things a minute as a commander can screw everyone over.

The pressure to perform well moment to moment has, sadly, turned the community pretty sour, much like a game like League of Legends. Even simple failings of the team like failing to act quickly in the face of overwhelming amounts of information (for instance, constant references to named map locations) can cause commanders to exasperate Geez
recommended: we have NO teamwork going on". Worse
hoursPlayed: if the team doesn't vote to concede
voteText: a completely lost match will drag on for half an hour with no map change. (Unlike a game like League of Legends
helpfulPercent: there's just no opportunities for comebacks - the entire resource system of the game encourages the "rolling wrecking ball" mentality)\n\nPerhaps this game would be fun with months of practice
votesHelpful: played solely with players who have similar amounts of experience; but even if you can get that first goal you'd likely just become one of the aforementioned commanders."

reviewText:
Simply and plainly one of the best FPS/RTS hybrid games available on the market.

Where other games of this genre are lacking Natural selection 2 makes up for with unique a symetrical combat versus a vile alien race. Unlike most games of this type fighting against an enemy team of a COMPLETELY different makeup and abilities to your own makes quite interesting and pulse pounding games. Often ending is a very real struggle on both sides with team work, almost inherently making even the most random and public of games competitive.

On top of this Natural Selection 2 is one of the few PC games that remains open source, coming with everything from the level designer to a PDF file explaining the dynamics of map making and how to make one that is balanced, the same PDF i assume Unknown worlds gives to their employees. Best of all, the developers take the time to listen to the community, engaging in conversation and discussions daily. In fact, being a player who has been around since early alpha i know a number of features in the game, good features, were designed by players like you are me and implemented with the help of the developers.

Natural Selection 2 is a gem for its time, one of the last PC games to still embrace the community as PC games used to do.

reviewText:
I've followed this game since it was a MOD for Halflife 1, and been part of the beta from the start, and this game has a very interesting gameplay which is very beautiful and very dynamic due to the freedom the players have in developing their tactics.

Each team has a commander whom handle the team resources, which is used to buy upgrades, buildings and abilities. Teamwork is a must in this game since both soldiers/commander are dependent on each others performance. You might be all hot and cool at shooters, but that doesn't mean you are gona win.

So, if you like munching marines or firering at poor aliens in small vents, this is a game for you.
voteText: 1 person found this review helpful

reviewText:
You remember the Alien vs. Predator frenchise back in the day? Before Half Life 2? This is it at it's core. And then, it isn't.
Natural Selection 2 is a competitive FPS-RTS mix that features asymmetrical gameplay. A team of Marines is put against a team of aliens that play entirely different while one player of each team serves as an overseeing commander from a top-down perspective. As commander you have to put down buildings like ressource extractors, armories, robotic facilities or buildings that provide upgrades for your little and ever complaining servants. This mode actually plays quite a lot like Starcraft or Command & Conquer for example. At least most of the times. You can even issue specific orders to individual team members. Following these orders and the way they are executing them is completely up them though.

While the commander and his skill is certainly critical to the success of your team, the personal skill of every soldier/alien matters almost as equally. But teamplay is objectively the most critical. A team that communicates a steady flow of information is already half way through the match.

There is quite a lot of maps shipped with the game and an almost infinite number of custom made maps as well as different game modes. The basic mode though puts you on a map with usually 5 locations where a command terminal or hive can be set up. These are needed for your commander to do his job. If you loose all of your Command terminals / Hives you loose the game. You start with one prebuild at a random location together with your first ressource extractor that provide a slow tick of ressources, both for the commander to spend on buildings, upgrades etc and for every player seperately to spend on personal equipment (Weapons, Armor, perks, ...). In case of the Marines you also start with a single Infantry Portal on which dead marines can respawn. Aliens hatch from eggs that spawn near a Hive at a slow rate.
So the immediate goal is to expand to other ressource nodes, build up you base and defend it and eventually destroy the enemie's bases. It's a game about map control like you would expect from a competitive RTS, so usually the team that holds the majority of ressource nodes for an extended period of time wins the game. Usually.

So much for the gameplay. What's it mechanically? It's a fast paced shooter that orientates itself along older titles like said Alien vs. Predator, Unreal Tournament, even Counter Strike for a certain degree. Weapons don't nessecarily act realistically. It is more important to keep the cursor on target than it is precisely aim or shoot in bursts to maintain a narrow spread. Aliens regenerate health at a slow rate but marines need medipacks that are dropped by the commander or an armory to get back up to full health. In addition they need a teammate with a welder to fix any armor points lost.
So, pretty old school but with an interesting twist and certainly a focus on teamplay.
Gameplay mechanics for the commander are deskribed in one word: Starcraft. It's an established formula and it works fine. Hotkeys, hotkeys, hotkeys. Every building and every equipment you may drop as commander is sorted in different categories (basic buildings, advanced buildings, etc.) and mapped to a specific key. (Controls are fully rebindable by the way). That's it. It's pretty easy to pick up although quite hard to be good at.

Technically and graphically the game is not really state of the art. It is not an ugly game and the texture quality is reasonably good. Animations work fine although they might look a bit silly from time to time. Where it really shines is it's dense, almost claustrophobic atmosphere and the ammount of adjustable game and graphics options as well as it featuring a good, old fashioned server browser and full mod support.
It's a PC game so why would you not want to pick a server based in your country with a low ping instead of being randomly assigned some server at the end of the world where not a single person speaks a language you recognise and you lag yourself through the map? Server browsers are your best friend in any FPS and Natural Selection 2 has one so... go for it.

If you like Counter Strike but would like to try something that puts two teams with entirely different strengthes and weaknesses against each other while maintaining a high degree of competitive gameplay then Natural Selection 2 is a thing you will most certainly enjoy.
If you already enjoyed it's predecessor or Alien vs. Predator back in the day but the graphics get a bit old for you then this is an absolute no-brainer. Buy it. Love it.

One thing to keep in mind though is that the developer pretty much ceased any support and further development to be able to concentrate on their current project. Although there are still frequent content updates and plenty of bugfixes provided by the community team that officially took over and so far the changes that were made by this team improved the game in many aspects.

reviewText:
It's a great FPS-RTS hybrid with unique game mechanics and asymmetric gameplay.

One player on each side takes the position of the commander and sees the battlefield like an RTS game. He issues commands and places structures that have to be build an defended by the other players. The other players see the world from the FPS perspective.

This isn't CoD or BF! If a team doesn't work together, it usually gets crushed in a few minutes. So you really need to work together since there is no unit that can survive alone! I can't say this often enough! Remember to obey and help your commander and use your voice chat to report enemy movements etc!

Playing as a human marine is similar to other shooters save for the team dependency. What really makes this game unique is the alien side. Since this game features asymmetric  gameplay, the developers made sure that the two teams play completely different. The aliens see the world through their mouth, bite and spit at enemies, climb walls, cloak and evolve into oher lifeforms.

The game is incredibely fun if you play in a team that works together. Make sure to watch at least this short official tutorial before you start to play: http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=_Sbi-9loqvA

reviewText:
As a Half-Life fan, I heard of this mod long time ago - but never played it. I bought the new edition last year (mainly to support the developers) and was a bit scared by the fact that they built their own engine. After trying it out I was impressed by the visuals and gameplay, but unhappy with performance and mouse input. Because of that, the game did not draw my attention for too long.

Lately, I gave NS2 a second chance and must admit that they put great effort into updates. You can use raw mouse input and the performance has increased dramatically. Furthermore the skill level is quite high (I think there is a competitive scene) and it is really fun to fool around as a total noob on public servers.

The aiming skills needed are different (in comparision to e. g. Counter-Strike) because aliens are very fast, can be nearly everywhere and a lot of close combat situations arise. The RTS part of the game (commanding) seems to introduce a lot of cooperation and teamwork even to public servers.

There are always full servers and the community is surprisingly friendly (voice communication is quite common). This is a great game, worth to buy even at full price - if you have time to play.

reviewText: Natural Selection 2 is a near-perfect asymmetrical multiplayer game that integrates the real-time strategy and first-person shooter genres into one package. In Natural Selection 2, there are two teams: the marines, and the aliens. The marines work kind of like your typical first-person shooter. They are, however, led by a commander who can drop health and ammo for the marines as well as placing structures around the map for them to build on their quest for victory. The aliens work a little differently; they tend to fight more effectively in close quarters situations, unlike the marines who can shoot from a distance. The alien players can also evolve into more advanced life forms whom each have their own advantages and disadvantages. Just like the marines, the aliens have a commander. The alien commander works much more independently than the marine commander; however, the alien commander can still provide a lot of support for his team with the structues that he or she builds and the upgrade paths that he or she chooses. The asymmetrical gameplay along with the combination of two outstanding game genres means that there is never really a dull moment, as every match can be interesting in its own way. I definitely recommend that you atleast give Natural Selection 2 a chance.

reviewText:
I played NS2 for over a thousand hours. I would give it a 8/10 in the current state.

Positive
it is very different to other games:
- 2 completely different teams
- Many weapons/lifeforms/upgrades are unlockable
- You can play as a strategic commander
-This makes the game very dynamic and gives you an insane amount of possibilities, tactics and   situation you can find yourself in between.
- The gameplay is very fast
- The community is very helpful. Ask any game related question on a Server: You will get helpful answers!

Negative:
- High system requierements
- Very complex at the beginning (You won't understand much and you will get killed very often)

It is still possible to learn this game. Once you know how to play it, it will be one of the most awesome games you can have and it makes fun for many many hours. All other FPS games will be very easy compared to NS2.

reviewText:
Simply and plainly one of the best FPS/RTS hybrid games available on the market.

Where other games of this genre are lacking Natural selection 2 makes up for with unique a symetrical combat versus a vile alien race. Unlike most games of this type fighting against an enemy team of a COMPLETELY different makeup and abilities to your own makes quite interesting and pulse pounding games. Often ending is a very real struggle on both sides with team work, almost inherently making even the most random and public of games competitive.

On top of this Natural Selection 2 is one of the few PC games that remains open source, coming with everything from the level designer to a PDF file explaining the dynamics of map making and how to make one that is balanced, the same PDF i assume Unknown worlds gives to their employees. Best of all, the developers take the time to listen to the community, engaging in conversation and discussions daily. In fact, being a player who has been around since early alpha i know a number of features in the game, good features, were designed by players like you are me and implemented with the help of the developers.

Natural Selection 2 is a gem for its time, one of the last PC games to still embrace the community as PC games used to do.

reviewText:
Starting as a mod for HL1 that I have played for hundreds of hours, this has evolved into a terrific game. A team of aliens plays versus marines, each having a commander that controls their team from above in a RTS style gameplay making this team-shooter a unique game with a unique gameplay.

The gameplay is very quick, especially when playing on the alien side due to the high movement speeds, but still strategy is paramount to win in this game.

Some points I especially like:
+ Completely different gamplay, based on which side you are on
+ Offers possibilities for slower/more relaxed players (Use the Gorge form as alien - building structures, supporting your team; Welder as marine - repairing structures/armor of players)
+ Succesively unlocking new items in the tech tree diversifies games
+ Having a commander gives the game a special feel"
+ Teamplay is encouraged
+ Huge choice of upgrades/weapons
+ Playing as commander is absolutely huge and an excellent experience

There are also some things I don't like but they are negligible towards the positive points:
- Finding someone to play commander on your team is often difficult on public servers
- The success of a game depends heavily/ultimately on the skills of your commander
- Overwhelming the marine team after a long game as aliens can be very tedious and lengthy
date: even after the whole map apart from one base is under alien control. Marines are able to easily defend a single base.\n\nI think this game is a worthy purchase and I can only recommend playing it. Thank you
hoursPlayed: January 9, 2014

reviewText:
Awesome FPS. With alien melee (safe for Lerk which can do a lot at range and the Gorge though it should rather build). Real time strategy is a required element for one guy on each team, through the commander chair.

Natural Selection leads to a diversity of play to be enjoyed for hours. It can be a bit frustrating to pick up, though I enjoyed the complexity from the start. “Tanking” a “big ♥♥♥ Donkey” can be an enjoyable experience even while loosing. You can’t be blamed for feeding (well not is standard play) so stick to it and keep an eye on the map and radar {tip}.

If you want more strategy or want to dictate the flow of the game jump into the commander seat. Though most people require one to have a mic for this role as communication is important esp. if your team does not ping or keep an eye on the map.

Balance is a bit of a dynamic perspective. It is balanced, though you might not think it at times and the whole thing can change around the next patch corner.
Latency is not so damaging so you can have fun in global games. Though you might just get frustrated at dying, when running around corners.

reviewText:
OMG this game is one of the best games i've ever played! It combines perfectly RTS and all good shooters have to got. You can play in many different servers with a lot of players which will be divided in two teams: Marines and Aliens. While one of your teammates (or even you) is the commander, the others have to help him building different tipes of constructions and, of course kill and destroy enemy constructions.
What happens if you are getting bored of being the commander? No problem, my friend! You can exit from the commander base whenever you want, and you only have to wait if other mate wants to be the commander. Just follow one rule: There must always be a commander, if not, your team is lost.
Bored of being always shooting to little aliens? Then switch side when another round starts.
You can decde your side before the game starts so look carefully to the advantages and disadvantages of each one:
-Marines have different weapons and upgrades of ther armours and weapons. They can even buy powerfull machines to help them. They are a perfect choice if you prefer a direct stile of shooting and go with your mates to battle.
-Aliens have a more stealthy style. They can go by vents and make surprise attacks to alone marines. For this they all have like darkvision and they are very rapid. You can even evolve to different aliens with different tipes of attacks and movement, like fly, climb the walls or go as fast as it looks like you are teleporting yourself!
Definitely, Natural Selection 2 is a game that won't disappoint you, and I highly recommend it.
voteText: 1 person found this review helpful

reviewText:
A visceral and fast paced multiplayer shooter combined with real time strategy make for Natural Selection's strengths. Gameplay involves either being on the ground or in the commander's seat, fusing beautifully the first person shooter and the real time strategy genres.

Numerous weapons and classes are available for both the Marines and the Kharaa, this allows for diverse play and keeps the game interesting. From the humble skulk, running on the ceilings and dropping in on unsuspecting victims. To the gargantuan and brutish Onos, smashing everything in it's path and reducing Marine machines to their component parts in seconds. There's a class for all kinds of players on both sides. Want to run around fearing for your life? Stick with your bog-standard infantryman. Want to go crazy and toe-to-toe with an Onos? Get yourself a mech and be feared by the Kharaa.

WIth hours of replayability, servers up 24/7, and a well balanced system of play. Natural Selection 2 is by far one of my favourite games of all time. Go ahead, buy it. I'll be waiting on the ceiling round the corner.

reviewText: It's Natural Selection 2!  If you ever played the predecessor, a mod for Half-Life, then you are familiar with the concept.  It's a blend of some RTS elements into an FPS game, pitting aliens against humans.   As an Alien you can evolve to a number of different species, from flying Lerks to the massive bull-like Onos.   As a human, you're more limited by what your command chair player gives you.  They'll give you objectives for new structures to build, give you weaponry to equip yourself with, and research new tech for your team.\n\nThe only gripe I have is with the balancing of the two sides, it's been disappointing at times in the beta and retail lifespan.

reviewText: Ns2 is a very entertaining game. It features great depth, lots of maps, and two very distinct sides. I am not going to go into detail explaining every element, as that would be like trying to molecular science in a single post, but basically, the game is a team based fps, pitting humans against aliens, in large, well designed maps. reviewText: Natural Selection 2 is a near-perfect asymmetrical multiplayer game that integrates the real-time strategy and first-person shooter genres into one package. In Natural Selection 2, there are two teams: the marines, and the aliens. The marines work kind of like your typical first-person shooter. They are, however, led by a commander who can drop health and ammo for the marines as well as placing structures around the map for them to build on their quest for victory. The aliens work a little differently; they tend to fight more effectively in close quarters situations, unlike the marines who can shoot from a distance. The alien players can also evolve into more advanced life forms whom each have their own advantages and disadvantages. Just like the marines, the aliens have a commander. The alien commander works much more independently than the marine commander; however, the alien commander can still provide a lot of support for his team with the structues that he or she builds and the upgrade paths that he or she chooses. The asymmetrical gameplay along with the combination of two outstanding game genres means that there is never really a dull moment, as every match can be interesting in its own way. I definitely recommend that you atleast give Natural Selection 2 a chance.

reviewText:
I played NS2 for over a thousand hours. I would give it a 8/10 in the current state.

Positive
it is very different to other games:
- 2 completely different teams
- Many weapons/lifeforms/upgrades are unlockable
- You can play as a strategic commander
-This makes the game very dynamic and gives you an insane amount of possibilities, tactics and   situation you can find yourself in between.
- The gameplay is very fast
- The community is very helpful. Ask any game related question on a Server: You will get helpful answers!

Negative:
- High system requierements
- Very complex at the beginning (You won't understand much and you will get killed very often)

It is still possible to learn this game. Once you know how to play it, it will be one of the most awesome games you can have and it makes fun for many many hours. All other FPS games will be very easy compared to NS2.

reviewText:
pros: asymmetrical factions, gameplay with depth, a great blend of fps and rts, good video options menu and visuals, great soundtrack, the tech tree for aliens shows the evolution and tech trees available to the player during a game, great server browser menu

cons: steep learning curve with a weak tutorial, difficult to navigate (you have to constantly bring up the mini map to find where you are and the map icons look messy), the tech tree for marines isn't readily available to see during a game

Overall, a great game concept executed very well - but fails to fully tackle the steep learning curve that new players face. The expansive map design is one of this game's strength but also one of its greatest weakness.
Natural Selection 2 is a hit or miss.

reviewText: Great multiplayer game. Each side plays completely differently but they're fairly well balanced. I played the early releases of the original Half-Life mod and it's just as fun as I remember. The graphics are very good, though a few more notches inbetween 'high' and 'off' on some of the settings would be nice.\n\nI'd heard Linux support was pretty bad early on (more like a public beta than a full release,) but it seems to have improved greatly since then. Performance seems to be about the same as the Windows version (I tried both,) and I've only had one random crash to the desktop in about 6 hours of play which was during the tutorial, not in online play. This is on Xubuntu 13.10 using the nVidia 331.20 driver (which I got from the x-swat repository). I recommend anyone attempting to play upgrades to the 331.20 driver because the 319 driver that ships with current *buntu distros gives me about 15fps less and regular (every 10 minutes or so,) crashes to the desktop.

reviewText:
Starting as a mod for HL1 that I have played for hundreds of hours, this has evolved into a terrific game. A team of aliens plays versus marines, each having a commander that controls their team from above in a RTS style gameplay making this team-shooter a unique game with a unique gameplay.

The gameplay is very quick, especially when playing on the alien side due to the high movement speeds, but still strategy is paramount to win in this game.

Some points I especially like:
+ Completely different gamplay, based on which side you are on
+ Offers possibilities for slower/more relaxed players (Use the Gorge form as alien - building structures, supporting your team; Welder as marine - repairing structures/armor of players)
+ Succesively unlocking new items in the tech tree diversifies games
+ Having a commander gives the game a special feel"
+ Teamplay is encouraged
+ Huge choice of upgrades/weapons
+ Playing as commander is absolutely huge and an excellent experience

There are also some things I don't like but they are negligible towards the positive points:
- Finding someone to play commander on your team is often difficult on public servers
- The success of a game depends heavily/ultimately on the skills of your commander
- Overwhelming the marine team after a long game as aliens can be very tedious and lengthy
date: even after the whole map apart from one base is under alien control. Marines are able to easily defend a single base.\n\nI think this game is a worthy purchase and I can only recommend playing it. Thank you

reviewText: First Person Shooter crossed with an RTS. Marines Vs Aliens in a fight to take out the other's base. Each side is led by a commander who views the game in a Top-Down style RTS view. Their soldiers are controlled by other players in First-Person. Lots of weapons, upgrades, and equipment keep the game interesting depending on which order they are researched by the commander.\n\nEach team plays differently, but each also has an incredibly high learning curve. This game is not for the impatient or the lone-wolf. This is a team-based game. Players that don't work together will die, teams that are divided will lose. Coordination, communication, and tactics are far more valuable weapons than any Railgun or Onos.

reviewText:
This is a pretty awesome game.

You play as either an Alien or as a Marine. Marines like to use guns, Aliens like to nom Marines and are faster.

Both sides have a commander who builds structures for the team and play this FPS as an RTS instead. They use resources from resource points that they've built on or gotten team-mates to build on. These then are used to get more tech and upgrades for everyone else.

Everyone else also gets resources from their controlled resource points. Aliens use them to evolve into different Aliens (and to place structures as Gorge) such as rhinos (Onos), whilst Marines use them to get different guns and jetpacks and mechs.

So your goal is to eliminate all the enemy players by either destroying their respawn buildings and/or command structures. To do this hold more resource points so you get upgrades faster, and go destroy enemy buildings / people with better weapons/aliens so that the enemy team loses their resources.

Have fun nomming people/shooting things/bossing people around!

reviewText: Natural Selection 2 has moments of beauty, where it’s easy to get wrapped up in the intense fighting, but other times it shows its low-budget roots. Marines, and the various forms of Aliens, all look like clones of one another. The environments are also pretty similar looking, though it’s hard to notice when you’re fighting for you life. I’ve also encountered a few issues where it locks up after failing to load a level properly. Even more frustrating is that there’s no way to group with friends to go into matches together, nor is there a way to see how far along a match is before you join. Smartly, though, the team has integrated mod support into the main menu, and it’s great to see how active the community has been in implementing new skins and the like into Steamworks.

reviewText:
Natural Selection 2 is a game featuring two exciting factions! Here are some features!

Marines
-Die alot
-Can spam buttons for medkits and ammo!
-Get accused of aimbots!
-An AR for spraying endlessly!
-A shotguns for missing shots that count!
-2 types of grenades and one that serves no purpose!
-Fire and Explosions
-Giant robots made of paper mache

Aliens
-Die more
-Yell at commander for upgrades!
-Get accused for aimbotting as lerk(?)!
-Variety of new tastes
-Taste kneecaps and teleporters
-Play as gorge to throw up new tastes/build treehouses

Additional Features
-Green names to yell at and blame losses on!
-Yellow names to yell at and blame losses on!
-Badges to yell at and blame losses on!
-Ability to vote to quit games!
-Ability to eject the man in charge!
-Ready room to idle in!

As you can see this game has many exciting features, and is a must buy for anyone who enjoys screaming, missing, dying, eating, being eaten, dinosaurs, and a community that is charming (the kind you don't want your parents to meet).

Buy now.

reviewText:
It's a great FPS-RTS hybrid with unique game mechanics and asymmetric gameplay.

One player on each side takes the position of the commander and sees the battlefield like an RTS game. He issues commands and places structures that have to be build an defended by the other players. The other players see the world from the FPS perspective.

This isn't CoD or BF! If a team doesn't work together, it usually gets crushed in a few minutes. So you really need to work together since there is no unit that can survive alone! I can't say this often enough! Remember to obey and help your commander and use your voice chat to report enemy movements etc!

Playing as a human marine is similar to other shooters save for the team dependency. What really makes this game unique is the alien side. Since this game features asymmetric  gameplay, the developers made sure that the two teams play completely different. The aliens see the world through their mouth, bite and spit at enemies, climb walls, cloak and evolve into oher lifeforms.

The game is incredibely fun if you play in a team that works together. Make sure to watch at least this short official tutorial before you start to play: http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=_Sbi-9loqvA

reviewText: Played both NS1 and 2.  This a a fantastic followup.  The graphics are nothing short of amazing. Wish I had more time to play but at least I have something to look forward to when I do.  As a veteran Unreal Tournament player I am quite happy with NS2.  Fun to play first person with nice focus on strat at the same time.  Great game!

reviewText:
I've followed this game since it was a MOD for Halflife 1, and been part of the beta from the start, and this game has a very interesting gameplay which is very beautiful and very dynamic due to the freedom the players have in developing their tactics.
