reviewText:
You remember the Alien vs. Predator frenchise back in the day? Before Half Life 2? This is it at it's core. And then, it isn't.
Natural Selection 2 is a competitive FPS-RTS mix that features asymmetrical gameplay. A team of Marines is put against a team of aliens that play entirely different while one player of each team serves as an overseeing commander from a top-down perspective. As commander you have to put down buildings like ressource extractors, armories, robotic facilities or buildings that provide upgrades for your little and ever complaining servants. This mode actually plays quite a lot like Starcraft or Command & Conquer for example. At least most of the times. You can even issue specific orders to individual team members. Following these orders and the way they are executing them is completely up them though.

While the commander and his skill is certainly critical to the success of your team, the personal skill of every soldier/alien matters almost as equally. But teamplay is objectively the most critical. A team that communicates a steady flow of information is already half way through the match.

There is quite a lot of maps shipped with the game and an almost infinite number of custom made maps as well as different game modes. The basic mode though puts you on a map with usually 5 locations where a command terminal or hive can be set up. These are needed for your commander to do his job. If you loose all of your Command terminals / Hives you loose the game. You start with one prebuild at a random location together with your first ressource extractor that provide a slow tick of ressources, both for the commander to spend on buildings, upgrades etc and for every player seperately to spend on personal equipment (Weapons, Armor, perks, ...). In case of the Marines you also start with a single Infantry Portal on which dead marines can respawn. Aliens hatch from eggs that spawn near a Hive at a slow rate.
So the immediate goal is to expand to other ressource nodes, build up you base and defend it and eventually destroy the enemie's bases. It's a game about map control like you would expect from a competitive RTS, so usually the team that holds the majority of ressource nodes for an extended period of time wins the game. Usually.

So much for the gameplay. What's it mechanically? It's a fast paced shooter that orientates itself along older titles like said Alien vs. Predator, Unreal Tournament, even Counter Strike for a certain degree. Weapons don't nessecarily act realistically. It is more important to keep the cursor on target than it is precisely aim or shoot in bursts to maintain a narrow spread. Aliens regenerate health at a slow rate but marines need medipacks that are dropped by the commander or an armory to get back up to full health. In addition they need a teammate with a welder to fix any armor points lost.
So, pretty old school but with an interesting twist and certainly a focus on teamplay.
Gameplay mechanics for the commander are deskribed in one word: Starcraft. It's an established formula and it works fine. Hotkeys, hotkeys, hotkeys. Every building and every equipment you may drop as commander is sorted in different categories (basic buildings, advanced buildings, etc.) and mapped to a specific key. (Controls are fully rebindable by the way). That's it. It's pretty easy to pick up although quite hard to be good at.

Technically and graphically the game is not really state of the art. It is not an ugly game and the texture quality is reasonably good. Animations work fine although they might look a bit silly from time to time. Where it really shines is it's dense, almost claustrophobic atmosphere and the ammount of adjustable game and graphics options as well as it featuring a good, old fashioned server browser and full mod support.
It's a PC game so why would you not want to pick a server based in your country with a low ping instead of being randomly assigned some server at the end of the world where not a single person speaks a language you recognise and you lag yourself through the map? Server browsers are your best friend in any FPS and Natural Selection 2 has one so... go for it.

If you like Counter Strike but would like to try something that puts two teams with entirely different strengthes and weaknesses against each other while maintaining a high degree of competitive gameplay then Natural Selection 2 is a thing you will most certainly enjoy.
If you already enjoyed it's predecessor or Alien vs. Predator back in the day but the graphics get a bit old for you then this is an absolute no-brainer. Buy it. Love it.

One thing to keep in mind though is that the developer pretty much ceased any support and further development to be able to concentrate on their current project. Although there are still frequent content updates and plenty of bugfixes provided by the community team that officially took over and so far the changes that were made by this team improved the game in many aspects.

reviewText:
As a Half-Life fan, I heard of this mod long time ago - but never played it. I bought the new edition last year (mainly to support the developers) and was a bit scared by the fact that they built their own engine. After trying it out I was impressed by the visuals and gameplay, but unhappy with performance and mouse input. Because of that, the game did not draw my attention for too long.

Lately, I gave NS2 a second chance and must admit that they put great effort into updates. You can use raw mouse input and the performance has increased dramatically. Furthermore the skill level is quite high (I think there is a competitive scene) and it is really fun to fool around as a total noob on public servers.

The aiming skills needed are different (in comparision to e. g. Counter-Strike) because aliens are very fast, can be nearly everywhere and a lot of close combat situations arise. The RTS part of the game (commanding) seems to introduce a lot of cooperation and teamwork even to public servers.

There are always full servers and the community is surprisingly friendly (voice communication is quite common). This is a great game, worth to buy even at full price - if you have time to play.

reviewText:
Awesome multiplayer FPS/RTS/Stealth game pitting the Marines against the alien race Kharaa.
Good co-op is extremely important with the marines having different infantry weapons (all of which are good in their own right and have their own drawbacks) such as assault rifle- shotgun- grenade launcher- flamethrower- and the Exo which is a big, tough but slow armored walker sporting 1 or 2 hard hitting chainguns.

Also includes support items for infantry such as welders for repairing structures and infantry and Exo armor. And jet-packs to greatly enhance the speed and mobility of infantry.

This put up against the Kharaa's arsenal of lifeforms including:
The small, fast moving, wall and celing crawling Skulk
The support and builder-class Gorge
The flying and obnoxious gas-farting Lerk
The in-and-out-of-battle blinking assassin-class Fade
And the massive and extremely tough marine-stomping and goring Onos.

But there's more!! Both sides are critically dependent on a competent commander viewing it all from an RTS point of view, setting up structures, researching upgrades, new gear and abilities, dropping supplies in times of need and advicing the forces in their quest to destroy the enemy. Will you be that one commander leading your team to victory?? You're not even my real father!!!!! ♥♥♥♥ YOU ♥♥♥♥ YOU ♥♥♥♥ YOU!!!!!!

More here http://naturalselection.wikia.com/wiki/Kharaa_%28Natural_Selection_2%29

reviewText: Natural Selection 2 is an awesome cross between FPS and RTS, a RTFPSS if you will.  Each of the sides, Marine and Alien, have a commander that plays the RTS game, putting down buildings, managing upgrades and trying to direct the flow of battle; While all the other players on the team play the actual units.  Resources are harvested from certain points and go to both team resources that the commander spends and personal resources that can be used to buy weapons (for the marines) or evolve into new lifeforms (for the Kharaa).  The marines get the standard guns : starting with the machinegun and can purchase others such as a flamethrower, grenade launcher, welder or the ultimate Exo suit.  The Kharaa start as the skulk, angry little dogs, and can evolve into gorges (support/builder unit), Lerk (flying ranged unit), Fade (teleporting assassin) and finally the tanky Onos (large angry bull).\n\nAll in all it is a very fun game, and there is apparently a lot of moddability to the game as well so there is a lot of replay value.  I enjoy the game a lot and definitely recommend it.

reviewText:
This game is simply great.

I have played this game solidly for a while and still havent touched the majority of the games complex strategy. The game can take a while to get used to but if you stick with it you will find a deeply satisfying FPS with some intrigueing RTS elements.

And i can't stress how amazing it feels when you pull off a successful manouvre with your team, bringing you closer to a victory.
Every kill feels like you have achieved something, more than i can say for other FPS's, and taking down some of the other teams buildings also feels great. The shooting is tight and satisfying, and the alien combat is far more polished than anything else i've seen like it. This game is what alien colonial marines multiplayer could've been

Not to mention the amazing mods, and extra gamemodes. Grab the game now, it still has an amazing, supportive community and much fun is to be had

reviewText:
Should you buy Natural Selection 2?

So firstly, what is Natural Selection 2?
Natural Selection 2 is a multiplayer only, Strategy/FPS hybrid (a mixture of the strategy and first person shooter genres) created by Unknown Worlds, in which marines face off against aliens in a fight for map domination. It was origonally a mod for Half-Life published over 10 years ago. One player from each team elects to be commander and plays the game similar to a real time strategy. All the other players either become a marine or an alien (depending on the team a player is on) and plays the game in a more FPS style.

What is the gameplay like?
Natural Selection 2 is not an easy game by any means. It relies heavily on teamwork as well as personal skill. The most critical roles in the game is the commander as he/she is responsible for co-ordinating the team, placing structures, managing resources and choosing upgrades. For this reason, it is highly recommended that people new to the game (< 10 hours) do not command on public servers. Moving on, marines play like most other FPS's, with their primary weapon being a gun. Everyone spawns in as a marine and can buy weapons and utilities from structures such as armories. When a marine is killed, he/she respawns from one of the infantry portals placed by the commander. As for the aliens, everyone spawns in as a basic alien call a skulk. Skulks have the ability to run up walls and bite for their primary attack. An alien can also evolve (works similar to buying) into other life forms. These other life forms consist of the gorge (an engineer/medic support life form), the lerk (a flying alien with ranged attacks), the fade (an assassin like alien which can use blinking" to move very fast) and the onos (a big rhino looking creature). When an alien dies
date: he/she becomes one of the team's eggs around a hive (an alien command structure) and hatches after a few seconds. The game is heavily resource based
recommended: with each team battling for the numerous resource nodes scattered around the map. Because of this
hoursPlayed: the balance of power can snowball if a team gets a poor start. Games usually last for around 20 minutes
voteText:
although there is always the odd 1 hour long games (which are usually very tense).

Do I recommend this game?
I would recommend this game to anyone if they are intrested in games in the strategy and FPS genre. However
helpfulPercent: this game requires quite a few hours to grasp the concepts and its community is slowly shrinking
votesHelpful: so if you have friends who have lots of spare time of their hands
votesTotal:
it might be worth picking this up during a sale and giving it a go. (Plus playing with friends is always lots more fun)

Pros:
Asymmetrical gameplay
Good mix of RTS and FPS

Cons:
Steep learning curve
Small community"

reviewText:
This game be awesome, you go pew pew as marines, and om-nom-nom as the aliens.

As marines: Your objective is to destroy all the hives of the aliens, one person takes the commander seat and  goes into RTS mode and builds the bases and supplies marines with health or ammo during battle, and controls some NPC's, rest of players are in the FPS style (Yes theres also resources)

As aliens: One person also goes into RTS style, but the players are in a Mouth-view-perspective and generally try to bite the marines, you use resources to evolve into stronger aliens, one can build minor defensive structures and heal, another flies and shoots, another can fade/teleport and slash through groups, and theres the Onoes, the big fat tank.

...yeah to keep it short, awesome game.

reviewText: It's not perfect, just like any game, but this is one of, if not the, best game in my library. It's a multiplayer shooter/RTS hybrid, as in; if you're the commander, you have a top down view and can build structures, order troops, and more. Although the two teams, (alien and marine) are completely different, it is balanced better than any game in existence that offers aesymmetical gameplay. The marines are more like your standard shooter, but there's no aim down sights, like many of the best tactical shooters such as CS, but the aliens are the most fun, with their in-mouth view. With the aliens, you can evolve to different species, you start off as a skulk, then, (in order of cost) Gorge, the healer, the Lerk, A flying Creature, The Fade, with it's deadly claws and blink ability. Then there is the Onos, the tank. All these are brought with resources, which you get for capturing res towers and holding them. It's the best multiplayer game I've ever played.\n\nTL;DR: WHY ARE YOU READING THIS GO BUY IT!

reviewText: Natural Selection II is probably the best multiplayer game I've played yet. Something this fun and interesting could really only come from an indie studio, plus it has the look and feel of a triple-A title. It's all competitive multiplayer that has a play-style for everyone; definitely my new obsession. There's a lot of new mechanics, so after a few games you'll want to check out the tutorial menu, but the community's always willing to help new players and commanders are great for pointing you in the right direction. Professional ankle-biting here I come! 10/10
voteText: 1 person found this review helpful

reviewText:
Awesome multiplayer FPS/RTS/Stealth game pitting the Marines against the alien race Kharaa.
Good co-op is extremely important with the marines having different infantry weapons (all of which are good in their own right and have their own drawbacks) such as assault rifle- shotgun- grenade launcher- flamethrower- and the Exo which is a big, tough but slow armored walker sporting 1 or 2 hard hitting chainguns.

Also includes support items for infantry such as welders for repairing structures and infantry and Exo armor. And jet-packs to greatly enhance the speed and mobility of infantry.

This put up against the Kharaa's arsenal of lifeforms including:
The small, fast moving, wall and celing crawling Skulk
The support and builder-class Gorge
The flying and obnoxious gas-farting Lerk
The in-and-out-of-battle blinking assassin-class Fade
And the massive and extremely tough marine-stomping and goring Onos.

But there's more!! Both sides are critically dependent on a competent commander viewing it all from an RTS point of view, setting up structures, researching upgrades, new gear and abilities, dropping supplies in times of need and advicing the forces in their quest to destroy the enemy. Will you be that one commander leading your team to victory?? You're not even my real father!!!!! ♥♥♥♥ YOU ♥♥♥♥ YOU ♥♥♥♥ YOU!!!!!!

More here http://naturalselection.wikia.com/wiki/Kharaa_%28Natural_Selection_2%29

reviewText: A good game. It requires more thought than most FPS games and a decent captain as well since yer commanda' pretty much controls evarythin' beyond th' playa's jus' killin' th' enemy

reviewText: It's certainly not the multiplayer experience everyone is after, and with no single-player component whatsoever, Natural Selection 2's appeal entirely depends on your desire for a complex, deep alternative to the usual immediacy of modern online shooters. There's potentially more balancing to be done when it comes to certain classes or abilities being slightly overpowered, but that's a matter of fine-tuned refinement rather than a vast overhaul. Right now it's an excellent game that taps into both the FPS and RTS markets, with plenty of varied builds and playing styles on offer. If competitive multiplayer gaming is survival of the fittest, then Natural Selection 2 is certainly fighting tooth and claw to reach the top tier.

reviewText:
This game is simply great.

I have played this game solidly for a while and still havent touched the majority of the games complex strategy. The game can take a while to get used to but if you stick with it you will find a deeply satisfying FPS with some intrigueing RTS elements.

And i can't stress how amazing it feels when you pull off a successful manouvre with your team, bringing you closer to a victory.
Every kill feels like you have achieved something, more than i can say for other FPS's, and taking down some of the other teams buildings also feels great. The shooting is tight and satisfying, and the alien combat is far more polished than anything else i've seen like it. This game is what alien colonial marines multiplayer could've been

Not to mention the amazing mods, and extra gamemodes. Grab the game now, it still has an amazing, supportive community and much fun is to be had

reviewText: NS2 is a good old aliens vs humans game, with the aliens being feral creatures that want to spread their hive over the map.  This game involves you and your team trying to kill the other team (duh) while captureing reasource nodes and command stations.  Each team has their players who play in a first person perspective, either be the Marines who use their guns, jetpack, mech suits, or the Kharaa (aliens) with their abilities to run on walls or ceilings, spore rooms, and much more.  Both sides need a comander who plays from a bird's eye view leading the team, building, and reasurching improvements.  Overall this game is about team work and depending on teams, matchs go from 5 min to 45 min.  *Warning this game has a steep learning curve.",February 14

reviewText: This is a very fun and addictive game, and the graphics are fantastic. My only problem with it is that there are not many options available to reduce draw times, for lower end PCs like mine, meaning that I rarely get a slightly decent framerate of even 20 frames per second on my machine. I can't complain because the developer's aren't to blame for my PC being terrible, but I would have liked to see more features able to be adjusted like texture quality and geometric complexity, since reducing the triangle count would certainly speed up draw times and make the game a lot more playable for people with less expensive machines like mine. Anyway, with that issue aside, the game is still very impressive and if it's on sale, I'd say go for it if you've got a nice GPU.

reviewText: I think this is one of the best games ever made. Brilliant strategic and tactical depth. Awesome graphics with perfect styling. Runs pretty good as long as the server isn't a toaster. Being competitively balanced it can lead to a few lopsided games for every balanced one you get, but when you get a balanced game it's a real trip and even better if you win. The marines struggle to stay alive, the way the alien creep spreads over the map and the lighting effects have to be experienced. It takes some effort to learn all the nuances (and you might not ever get it all) but that's what makes it good, definitely worth 10 bucks. Since there is nothing else like this game that competes, it will always have a player base, some of the NS2 players play nothing but NS2. Vets 99% of the time never have a problem helping new players but you got to be able to listen.

reviewText:
Fun game for a cheap price. Games can span anywhere from 10 minutes to 2 hours depending on how well the teams are balanced. Need to be strategic behind what you do in this game and it's not just a COD were you run around and shoot things. Requires communication with your commander who drops stuff for you and ensures upgrades were you are weak.

The community is awesome and people are very friendly. If your a noob just simply say so and ask were you are needed. Why? Because players communicate and commanders normally will tell you were to go if your not sure. I ran into a few people who were simply trolls/a-holes and my hole team told him to @$ck off and nobody ever backed him up. He shortly left and I hope he uninstalled.

The gameplay:
Play as MARINES at first because it's the most familiar play smart and stick with your group/don't split up. Keep your distance from the aliens and move strategically and communicate with your commander. ALIENS are more of ambushing and simply harder to play the MARINES and the ALIENS rely on MARINES being a little to cocky and pushing bad spots.

reviewText:
Date of Review: 04.2016
Playtime ~600hrs (Actual play time according to Hive Stats)

NS2 is a blend of strategy and shooter. I will not say unique"
date: since the word seems overused nowadays. What is unique about the game is that it actually implements 2 very different factions with very different playstyles while still staying moderately balanced. It is also unique in the way that the development team keeps the game updated and running
recommended: partially relying on community effort to do so.\n\nWithin the game the Marine faction represents the standard FPS gameplay of tactical movement and long range engagements. The Marines move slower through the map
hoursPlayed: but have a distinctive firepower advantage and can set up outposts a lot more quickly than the aliens. The Marine commander will have to juggle a lot betweeen setting up bases
voteText: maintaining resource income and supporting frontline troops. Marine field players will need to coordinate with the commander and each other in order to hold as much ground as they can without spreading their forces too much\n\nThe Alien faction has many lifeforms that have short range attacks and low hitpoints
helpfulPercent: especially in the beginning of the game. They rely on stealth and synergies between their abilites to ambush and overwhelm marines or sneak behind enemy lines to quickly destroy key structures. The Alien Commander can focus a lot more on supporting his team and can even leave his position in the Hive vacant for some time to assist in attacking or defending. Alien field players need to pick wisely when to invest resources in higher lifeforms and balance between doing the most possible damage and keeping their valuable lifeforms alive.\n\nAs an advise for new players I recommend to visit servers with a lower playercount first. The game is designed around teams with 6-8 players
votesHelpful: which further increases the steep learning curve on some of the high playercount servers. Also
votesTotal: I advise them not to be afraid of trying to play aliens at first. While playing as marine may be more familar to many
votesFunny: there are many things to learn and keep in mind at once that simply do not matter for alien players. Going for a high skill server while learning is okay
commentsCount:
however keep in mind that on servers with a high average skill the atmosphere can become a bit competetive.

Strenghts:

- The game has a strong emphasis on teamplay and tactical gameplay. While personal skill is also important the team with the better coordination
column16: even if it just by a part of the team
column17: can have a big impact on the outcome.\n\n- Both sides have a unique feel and playstyle to them
column18:
and a variety of weapons to cater to different preferences of playstyle.

- A very unique atmosphere that is supported by map design and faction design alike.

- Different map designs encourage different approaches in playstyle
column19: both personal and as a team.\n\n- The "community development team"
column20: hired by the developers to maintain the game
column21:
produces regular patches in coordination with the community to fix performance and gameplay issues.

Weaknesses:

- The Netcode could need some serious improvement
column22: with long range weapons facing against short range weapons differences in latency can have a huge negative impact when playing. I recommand searching servers with a latency (ping) of less than 100 (my experience suggests less than 50).\n\n- The playerbase is stable
column23: but small. There is a number of well populated servers
column24: however it is possible you come online at a time where all the "good" servers are full. With your ping in mind
column25: try out for yourself whether you want to wait for a slot on a server in your region or try your luck on one with a higher latency
column26: or with more/less skilled players than you.\n\n- For a new player
column27: the amount of things to learn can be overwhelming at first
column28: especially on marines. There are a number of gameplay mechanics that are not immediately clear to the player and need to be learned. Be not afraid to ask
column29: even if some of the experienced players may sound harsh
column30: there is always someone who will be willing to help.\n\n- The same goes for commanding. There is a lot about commanding that is not immediately apparant
column31: so you might not want to try it right off the bat. However
column32: messing around in offline sandbox mode might be good to get an idea of "what that commander is doing" while you are out fighting
column33: even if you are not interested in commanding.\n\nI recommend NS2 to anyone ready to invest some time into learning the game before actually having fun. There are a few initial hurdles to overcome if you want to play successfully. However once you become more accustumed to the mechanics this game can be fun and challenging to skilled and less skilled players alike. Also
column34: my personal experience with the players in NS2 is that there are quite a few helpful ones that you can get along with very well
column35: although you may need to take the initiative talk to them first. Many players are not used to the amount of communication NS2 requires for both teams
column36: so this factor might also require some effort from the side of the new player."

reviewText:
This game is a lot of fun. Its a wonderfull RTS/FPS hybrid, and the gameplay, especially with recent tweaks, is fast paced and exciting. Each team has a different playstyle, and the balance is set up very nicely. To list a few highlights:

At the beginning of each round, a player on each team can enter the Command Center (Hive for Aliens) and is granted a top down perspective of the game, just like a standard RTS. The commander places buildings, purchases upgrades, and issues orders, just like an RTS.

However, unlike a standard RTS, the units under his command do not have to follow orders, because these units are the other players. The other players play this game like a shooter, spending personal resources gained from building structures, killing enemies, and passively from secured resource points, to buy new weapons and equipment such as grenades for use.

The Aliens, however, do not purchase weapons or equipment with their resources. They evolve into other life forms, spawning as the generic Skulk, a fast moving but fragile wolf-like creature, and evolve traits, like enhanced speed, armor, or stealth.

One team wins if they destroy all of the other teams Command Posts/Hives.

reviewText:
The classic Alien Vs Marines FPS/RTS.

Evolve into different Alien forms. Spread your Zerg like alien growth across the map. Command your team in an RTS mode. Climb up the walls as the basic Alien life form. A fun and involved first person shooter.

Kill aliens, upgrade your guns. Build structures around the map, and compete for dominance..

This game is almost a Starcraft/CS/HL experience.


A complex game with a big learning curve, very rewarding once you have a good foundation of knowledge on the game.

A good sequel to a groundbreaking HL mod.

reviewText: I've got 732.7 hrs on record for this game (from closed beta), and I fully expect to have well over 2000 in the next year or two. This is a VERY RARE title. It blends so many elements from FPS, RTS, and even have mechanics from other genres like adventure games. NS2 captures the thrills of FPS combat, the tactical intruige of RTS, and the joy of winning in a team-based game. It can have some learning issues for new players, but once it clicks, once you understand the awesomeness of NS2, you will keep coming back again and again.\n\nThere is no single-play version, but there eventually will be due to how insanely moddable this game is. The entire custom engine was built with modding in mind. It has Steam Workshop support for maps, but will soon include support for full mods. Spark (the Engine/Platform NS2 runs on), dare I say, is more moddable than the original HL1 and look what came from it. The potential for entirely new games, variations of NS2 make this worth the price alone. Get it!!

reviewText:
Product received for free

Tremulous, Gloom and Natural Selection... Tbh its hard to choose which is the best out of the three.

Gloom is a fast paced frag-based with variation in the damage system, Tremulous is fast paced as well and can be fun as hell but often camping simulator, Natural Selection sucks whenever one team starts to lose and if that is your team, because all the players joining mid-game always join the winning team, and NS2's heavy reliance on teamstrategy makes it difficult to carry the team. However I do enjoy aliens and commander isn't so bad. The game also heavily relies on the fact marines can pick up weapons from corpses. I can imagine how aweful humans are when they are no longer able to pick up their weapons.

However as all three games go, they do have a gameplay trend: Human-biased with lots of players and alien-biased with little amount of players.

Oh well who cares its still fun.
voteText: 1 person found this review helpful

reviewText:
Natural Selection never got the love it deserved in my opinion. The marine team is essentially what I've always wanted FPS games to be like in the multiplayer section. A commander has a birds-eye view and can order marines specifically [Giving you, as the player, side objectives that help the team]. In most games I would complain about the ability to full auto and have such small spread, but you NEED it, as the aliens have a lot of finesse. This is truly a team game, where a high kill count and low death score isn't as important as securing strategic locations and getting resource nodes for your commander.

As Alien, it's a bit tricky. It's very easy to understand, but hard to master. This game often plays as a horror game, as good alien players often will ambush and surprise marine teams, making it hard to steady your aim. Onos has to be the most fun [In my opinion] to play, and let's even a noob who's willing to save up resources try out this behemoth of a xenomorph.

Trust me, you won't regret at least trying this game.

reviewText: Fun to play, but game qualtiy varies for each server. Commanders are often verbally assulted if they do not play up to par. I would recommend playing as a foot soldier to allow for a more stress free play. If you like RTS games then the commander chair is for you. Be sure to do some research on it before you play, because it can be overwhelming for first or second time commanders. While the first few games can be confusing, once you get the hang of it the game becomes pretty entertaining. Learning the hotkeys for pings and audio chat would be useful as well to ease communication between you and your team. Overall fun game, and can be really fun for a long time.

reviewText:
This is an awesome action packed game , both sides (marine/aliens) are well balanced and equiped to kill eachother.

Keep in mind ti's an older game and the community of NS2 Gamers has shrunk, but still allot of people can be found online at any moment, but it should be more!

The big weakness of this game is the fact that each team NEEDS a decent commander to win, and it can take a couple of games before you encounter one. Allot of sad lonely people also constantly complain to these commanders and make it very hard for new commandes to want to continue learning how. It's not easy.

That counts for this game in general. It's not easy. You dont get any free kills, you will often end a match with less kills then deaths by far, but if you help your team it will be very satisfying and you will care more about the victory then your score.

Allot of players have been playing it for years and they make up the hard core of the online community for this game, most of them are very nice but they can be vary impatient. reviewText: I have a hard time deciding on whether I love this game or hate it.  I was an avid player of the original Natural Selection late in it's lifetime.  The RTS-esque elements of NS2 are done very well, but they should provide you with an in-game tutorial to help guide you with the how-to's and when-to's of this element of the game.  Playing as the marines is basically a straight forward shooter. Where the game really seperates itself from the pack are playing as the aliens and the surprising amount of team work shown by members of the community playing this game.  I was very impressed with the community.  If you are seeking a different take on competitive FPS multiplayer games and a decently steep but short learning curve then this is the game for you!

reviewText:
Pros:
+ Great atmosphere and graphics
+ Awesome team-based gameplay
+ Controls are very smooth and the framerates are smooth as well
+ Very fun mix of countersrike, starcraft, and aliens vs predator

Cons:
- Very first match once you boot up the game has slightly longer load times
- Steep learning curve (but gives you a huge sense of reward once you get into the groove)

Preferred peripheral: Keyboard and Mouse (not sure if it works with a gamepad)

Personal Notes:
One of the most fun team-based games I have ever played. I really recommend this to everyone! Most of the people I've played with are very helpful provided that you communicate with the team. Playing with a headset is a must with this game.

Verdict: BUY AND SUPPORT THE DEVS!

reviewText:
---this review happened to be a long review. but i wrote down everything i thought about this game after 1500+ hours of gameplay, plus NS1 experience. first part is why you should buy the game. what makes the game so fun. second portion is about 'the reason why this game did not become one of the best selling game eventhought i praise this game in the first portion of the review'

do you like Starcraft? do you like FPS games? then this game is a go for you. This is a few FPS game in current market that you cannot just YOLO to win a round. You actually have to think, plan, many steps before the enemy. this game also requier multitasking skill. while you are rushing to your objective, while you are shotting at aliens, you re required to know what's happening in each location on the map.(if you can't do that, usually there are people with mic that inform you which room is being hit and which room is clear to move in and so on)
commanding is a whole differnt part of the game. you cannot just jump in the command chair without much experience as a field marine for good couple of hundreds of hours of gameplay time in NS2, but ironically, you do need to have experiences as a commander to understand the physiology of the game.
after that, you are supposed to think as a commander, do what commander would want a marine to do, when you are a field marine. that's how you win a game as a solid team, and that's the true jewel of this game.
this is what makes NS2 the best game i've ever played in my life, and trust me, i've been a  PC gamer for about 15 years. this teamwork requirement environment, this strategy heavy gamestyle is unparalleled to any other game with the same or similar expirence.

the only flaw is that UWE, the developer of this game, is a small company, plus they have been making terrible mistakes for the past year. and they might make more mistakes in the future because that's who they are.
1.they forced themselves to develop their own engine eventhough they lack human, capital resources. which is why it took years years for NS2 to be released.
2.due to #1, the game engine is very poorly coded and thus poorly optimized to any computer system. if you get 120FPS in BF4, expect to get 60FSP in this game at most.
3.there are only handful number of maps that are actually playable. there are custom made maps in workshop, but i've never seen a single map that is actually balanced and playable.(including jambi. jambi is the best custom map but at the same time, it's still unplayable) and UWE didn't care about having only 6 maps because they have less then 10 employee in their company, and they decided to spend their time on developing new mods(that is also broken to maximum level) changing balance here and there(that were unnecessary), changing maps(i mean ruining maps like docking), fixing bugs(thus making more bugs by the bugfix)
4.the game is unbalanced to public players since UWE only focus everything in the game for 6 vs 6 competitive matches. the best experience i had while playing this game was when i was playing in 30+, 40+ servers. but i'm not sure if UWE knows that they can't optimize the game to that level of server environment, or they really want to make this game like starcraft that pro  players compete in national league, but if you join a server that is 20+, you will notice that alien vs marine balance is broken. it's always marines that are stronger because they have guns, when both alien, and marine players are at exactly same level when it comes to skills and teamwork. i used to be ok with that. this asymmetric confrontation was what i loved the move about this game. the problem arose when UWE started to nerf down aliens and give marines more and more weapons, and more firepowers.
5.the game is laggie to its maximum level. you will notice that you actually get killed not because of your skill, but because of the lag issue. if you have 200+ ping, you will be almost a solid second behind what's really going on in the server. this is very ironic if you recall what i said about balancing. UWE is going for 6 vs 6 player balancing because they want to see more and more competitive matches and leagues, thus making 20+ server unbalanced. and i hear competitive league players complaining that they can't compete with other teams at their best condition because of the lag issue.

the reason why it sounds like i'm ranting every single thing about UWE is because i realized that it's in their nature. even though they are given with this awesome game concept, the execution was a fail, and i must say, they could have done something to prevent this. they could have become next blizzard. they could have made it next starcraft. they could have make the competitions shown on TV like starcraft. but UWE has failed and that's why you see 75% off sale every month for past 5 months. UWE finally accepted their failure. and the last thing i want to point out is that they started a donation program toward UWE at the same time as they started to promote the game with 75% sales. the company has some serious moral hazard. they chand the gameplay style upside down 6 months after the release and they've been doing that once a while, and oldbies like myself was thinking 'this is not what i've purchased, this is not what i've been trying so hard to be good at'.

Conclusion:
the strongest iron happened to meet its least skilled blacksmith. you will still have fun with it. but expect some flaws. and after playing awhile, you will face a unclimbablely stiff learning curve due to the game engine and lag.(you don't have to worry about this for the first couple of hundreds of hours because the game's learning curve is stiff at the beginning too)

reviewText:
Natural Seclection 2 is half First Person Shooter, half stategy game of space marines vs aliens. It really is a unique game because you can become a commander for your team like true real time strategy. However, I recommend that you NEED to wear headphones while playing. The commander and players like to use mics while communicating. So it will be hard to listen if you're just using speackers. Natural Selection 2 focuses on teamwork. So you cannot go guns blazing through the game like callofduty. Otherwise your team will lose altogether. You must trust and follow your commander's orders to win the game.

Overall: 8/10
The gameplay is one of a kind. You will not find a game like this. It's unique style is worth buying.

reviewText:
Very immersive and addictive game, as long as you work on your skills to keep up with the others.

Can be very frustrating for rookies. Small, but strong core community, although not everyone is rookie-friendly, because of imbalanced teams.

On the other hand, you can experience teamplay which you will not find anywhere else. You can never be sure who will win... the game can turn any moment, even if it looks like an easy win.

Does not work as a casual game and that's on purpose. Use eye drops.

reviewText: Great team based FPS game with interesting gameplay. Hardly anyone plays anymore but often there are surges in players during sales and sometimes on the weekends. Don't buy this guy if you want something you can pick up and play instantly with little to no searching. There is no matchmaking, and new people should stick to the newbie-friendly servers to learn the ropes. Some of the community is very elitist, but that's a given with small tight-knit communities.\n\nAlso just a warning, this game is VERY hardware intensive. It seems that it's rather poorly optimized and causes older GPUs to run very hot. Before I upgraded, my old NVIDIA GeForce GTX 760 would become dangerously hot (easily over 90C) if I played for long periods of time. I DO NOT RECOMMEND BUYING THIS GAME IF YOU HAVE A LOWER END GRAPHICS CARD.

reviewText: yes, yes i do.  like any community, especially a smaller one like this, there are going to be toxic players (and they are infamous) that give the community a bad rap.  and there are many players that are a little too good for the average pub  match, but because the number of servers with active games is so low, it's their only opportunity, and that tends to frustrate newer players that haven't grasped the difficult learning curve, especially on the alien side. but this community is largely a group of dedicated and passionate players that are a joy to play this game with. and yes, we suffer thru lopsided matches (oh it was so stacked that round!), because when you get a really good match and a well-played round, it is so totally awesome that you will suffer thru the drudge yet again in pursuit of that next great round high.  i have played far too much of this game, and i will play far too much more... nuff said

reviewText: This has got to be one of the most fun games I have played in a long time. The combination of RTS and FPS really go great together when you get a well-coordinated team. The feeling of a well-orchestrated battle and team work is really refreshing compared to other games that are all run and gun gameplay that other games have.
voteText: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
As someone who has dumped well over 1000 hours on Natural Selection 1, this game is on life support.

Its a great game that just has too many bad business decisions about it all around. The major crux in this game is making NS2 Combat as a Standalone buy seperately, just for a different game mode that was VERY popular in the NS1 days.

As such, thanks to this decision, NS Combat is like 8 or 9 bucks for a completely dead mode. Which sucks since Combat was a lot of high intensity fun! Even if Combat wasnt the main draw of NS, it kept a lot of players interested in the game to extend the lifespan of NS1 much longer than it should have as a mod.

The lack of respect shown from Unknown Worlds has shown to this great game is staggering. Opening up a skin store and making a exclusive marine weapon to buyers is another ♥♥♥♥♥♥ move to reward your longtime players.

That aside, this is a very fun team based game. I just wish that this could be absurdly popular as the NS1 days were. All love to making a great game better, but with no microtransactions.

reviewText:
This game is my absolute favorite of all time. But first I must warn you that this game have a HIGH learning curve! So please take your time to learn the game. Watch some tutorials. Play some games. Ask for help! I usually view anyone with less than 100 hours as a rookie. But just stay on the green servers for that time. And do not feel discouraged if you don't get many kills in the beginning. This game is not about killing. It's about team work!

Once that is said. Then I can only recommend this game. Knowing that it isn't for everyone. But there are many roles that needs to be filled in this game. So there are plenty of room for whatever you like.
Buy it. And have fun :)
Or work your way up to the competitive players.
